name: The ‘Australian' alps
description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

key_work.title: Ngaya (I Am)
key_work.credit_line:
With Rhian Hinkley and composer Harry Covill

Commissioned by ACMI
key_work.brief_description:
“Ngaya (I Am) is a cut-and-paste, punked-up look at my Country. It looks at Country from an insider-outsider perspective… and uses humour to disarm the viewer about the true nature of invasion.”

Shirtless men dance under a mirror ball and a jet ski skims flood waters as Ngarigo Country burns. Peter Waples-Crowe layers footage from tourism campaigns, ads for the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme and amateur YouTube movies, as well as newly recorded video and animations of his distinctive paintings. These visions of Ngarigo Country are collaged atop colonial paintings, including Eugene von Guérard’s “North-east view from the northern top of Mount Kosciusko” (1863).

Paintings like this perpetuated the myth of terra nullius, and Peter’s work dismantles the legacy of erasure and misrepresentation by interrogating the way non-Indigenous people construct images of Aboriginal land and people. Through this searing yet playful contrast, he mocks non-Indigenous visions of Country that view it as something to be stolen, owned and exploited – nothing but ski slopes and untapped riches.

As someone who views his Country from afar, Peter repurposes these fragmented images to piece together the multiple layers of his identity – proudly inserting them back into the landscape and proclaiming, ‘We are still here’.

start.title: The Man from Snowy River
start.brief_description: The Man From Snowy River, based on the classic Australian poem by Banjo Patterson, tells the story of an 18 year old boy who proves himself a man during an unforgettable chase on horseback down the rugged Snowy Mountains and becomes a legend. The most magnificent footage of horses ever filmed.

end.title: The Silver brumby
end.creator_credit: John Tatoulis, Colin South and Media World Features
end.brief_description: Based on Elyne Mitchell’s famous novel, “The Silver Brumby” is set in the Australian Alps, where a rogue stallion is king of the mob of horses which roam the awesome landscape. For years, the mountain men have tried to capture him, but with no success. One horseman is determined to succeed where others have failed and embarks on an unforgettable adventure. Starring Russell Crowe, Caroline Goodall and Ami Daemion.

links.description: The The Silver Brumby is set in the “Victorian High country”. Based on an old fable about the prince of the brumbies, the film follows one man’s impossible wish to tame the young stallion, Thowra. Like The Man from Snowy River is represents how settlers have tried to control the environment.

links.description: The bushranger is essential to the construction of Australia’s national identity. Kirk Dougla’s character exemplifies this in The Man from Snowy River with his rugged battle against the natural world. The mountains and bush are something to be tamed, a triumph of strength and masculinity - something that The Legend of Molly Johnson tries to counter.

end.title: The Snowy : A Dream of Growing Up
end.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Siobhan McHugh and Film Australia
end.brief_description: Australia’s Snowy Mountains Scheme is one of the world’s greatest engineering feats. The project to bring water to the dry west was built between 1949 and 1974, employing 100,000 people, many of them migrants who brought with them changes that have shaped Australia. This film documents Australia’s ambitious project using interviews and historical film. Based on the book “The Snowy : the People Behind the Power” by Siobhan McHugh.

links.description: The natural world as something to conquer and a signifier of progress is also captured in documentaries. The Snowy: a Dream of Growing Up tells the story of the 100,000 mostly immigrant workers who constructed the Snowy Mountain Hydro Scheme, one of the largest engineering feats in the world today.

links.description: Peter Waples-Crow’s Ngaya (I Am) critiques the conflicting narratives of Ngarigu country in mass media in his signature style, from skiing commercials to hunting videos, asking, whose mountain is it anyway? Goa-Gunggari-Wakka Wakka Murri woman Leah Purcel’s The Legend of Molly Johnson is also set in the region and reclaims the bushranger through an Indigenous lens.

end.title: Jindabyne
end.creator_credit: Ray Lawrence, Catherine Jarmar and April Films
end.brief_description: Based on the Raymond Carver short story “So much water so close to home”, this is a compelling drama about a marriage drawn asunder by a young girl’s murder. Stewart Kane, played by Irish actor Gabrielle Byrne, goes fishing with friends to a remote spot; when he and his friends find a young girl’s mutilated body they continue with their trip, reporting the crime upon their return. Such callousness makes Claire (Laura Linney) question her marriage and her husband’s humanity and she is drawn into a web of intrigue and ethical dilemmas. Expanding upon Carver’s original text, Lawrence examines Aboriginal rites and ceremonies and places, central to the narrative, the uncomfortable relationship between the black and white communities.

links.description: In Jindabyne, an Indigenous woman’s body is discovered by a group of fishermen, who delay reporting the crime to the police. Jindabye is filmed entirely on location in the town of the same name, situated right next to the Snowy Mountains, and also features Leah Purcell as Carol.
